name: Nalmefene (Selincro)
summary: An opioid receptor modulator used primarily to reduce alcohol consumption in adults with alcohol dependence.
description: Nalmefene is an opioid receptor modulator with antagonist activity at the mu- and delta-opioid receptors and partial agonist activity at the kappa-opioid receptor. It is primarily indicated for the reduction of alcohol consumption in adults with alcohol dependence who have a high drinking risk level but do not require immediate detoxification. Unlike naltrexone, nalmefene is often taken on an as-needed basis rather than daily.

monitoring_required: Signs of opioid withdrawal if patient is opioid-dependent

items: Reduction of alcohol consumption in adults with alcohol dependence who have a high drinking risk level

sections.text: Antagonizes mu- and delta-opioid receptors and partially agonizes kappa-opioid receptors, modulating the brain's reward pathways to reduce the reinforcing effects of alcohol.

adult.as_needed: 18 mg taken 1–2 hours before anticipated drinking; maximum one tablet per day

sections.hepatic_impairment: Contraindicated in severe hepatic impairment; use with caution in mild-to-moderate impairment
sections.renal_impairment: Use with caution; no dose adjustment in mild-to-moderate impairment

sections.text: Onset within 1–2 hours after administration; duration covers typical drinking session.

serious: precipitated opioid withdrawal in opioid-dependent patients

other: Do not use in patients currently dependent on opioids due to risk of precipitating withdrawal

items: Liver function tests before and during treatment

sections.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh potential risks; data are limited
sections.lactation: Unknown if excreted in human milk; caution advised
sections.geriatrics: Use with caution; monitor for side effects

sections.text: Not generally required; may discontinue abruptly if needed.

items: Intended for use in conjunction with psychosocial support
Can be taken on days when drinking is anticipated rather than daily
Not approved in the United States; available in certain European countries
